In our Semis- on- Fire Weekly, we strive to highlight differentiated insights and distill them into a short, video format. This week, we recap our meetings from our 2025 Semis conference and implications from NVDA & MRVL earnings. Video link here

Connectivity Top Theme. Connectivity has emerged as a constraint in AI systems as LLM parameters have increased to 20tr from 20bn over the past three years, and we think investment dollars will flow to those that solve that constraint. MTSI benefitting from 2 connectivity product cycles into 2026: 1) \(2^{\mathrm{nd}}\) wave of ACC demand, for 0- to- 3 meter interconnects at 1.6T speeds; and 2) LPO ramping starting SepQ at \(1^{\mathrm{st}}\) customer, \(2^{\mathrm{nd}}\) customer close behind. ALAB also benefitting with 10+ engagements w/ 10 unique customers for Scorpio X Scale- Up Switch Fabric targeting \(>52.5bn\) TAM by 2028.
AMD - DC Momentum Building. ROCm improving. Positive Mi355 ramp. Customer interest in both Mi400 and LT GPU roadmap - reminds us of customers buying EPYC 10yrs ago for LT CPU roadmap.

LRCX - Technology Transition Beneficiary. Healthy 1H26 visibility. Expect higher etch intensity w/ higher layer count conversion in NAND. GAA driving 3x expansion for metal dep SAM per wafer vs non- moly devices. AP demand remains strong.
Analog/MCU - No Fireworks, but Quiet Confidence. Cycle indicators continue to trend positively, but tariffs still delaying restocking cycle

NVDA JulQ Beat/Raise. Top Pick - Still AI Ecosystem of Choice. We highlight Compute ex- H20 revs grew \(12\%\) QQ and in our view higher OpEx reflects NVDA's goal to prosecute broadening set of opportunities in emerging AI markets. NWing revs \(+46\%\) QQ driven by growth in NVL- 72 system NVLink, Ethernet, Infiniband. Reiterate Top Pick.

MRVL JulQ Meet/Raise. Lumpy Custom AI Revs. We expect stock to consolidate as investors assess risk of NT custom silicon decline. In medium- term we think 20x PE is attractive for an AI play. Reiterate OP

Weekly Performance. This week, incl AH pricing for MRVL, SOX was \(+4\%\) vs S&P 500 \(+2\%\) . Outperformance led by RMBS (+15%), PI (+13%), NVM1 (+12%), MTSI (+8%) and TER (+8%). Key laggards included MRVL (- 7%), MCHP (- 1%).
Buy AI Connectivity Plays - MTSI, ALAB, NVDA Connectivity = constraint
ROCm improving.CSPs making decisions on LT roadmap
Tech transition beneficiary: NAND conversion, GAA, AP
1H26 visibility healthy

SourceQuoteTier 2 CSPThis year, it's all Grace Blackwell 200. We're working day-in, day-out, deploying it, integrating it and thenwaiting for the next shipment to comeTier 1 CSPOrders largely caught up to expectations 6 months ago, but demand grew over that period. Deployingmaterial quantity of racks/Q but largely in cooler regionsTier 1 CSPThey have a software that is called Dynamo software where it allows you to now sequentially parallelize thejob with taking each sequence on one GPU, so it does not have to wait anymore, even during inference. This is why I say you still need the large models and specifically the newer models from Nvidia and this is why Idon't see them slowing down at all to tell you the truth.Tier 1 CSPAvailability of GB200 was disappointing. A lot of cloud providers are waiting for GB300. I believe by at leastinstalling it by early next year, end of this year. This is why you see a surge on H100 because to your point,the demand doesn't wait, but H100 is very cheap now today compared to a GB200. Once GB300 is ready,you jump directly to GB300. We're taking H200 now as far as I can tell.Tier 1 CSPModels are getting more complex. We used to have a few years ago just 40 billion. Now there's trillion, billionparameters. The thing is you need higher-end GPU systems like Grace Blackwell 200, NVL72 racks or thenew UltraClusters for Trainium, if you want to train these in a decent amount of time, so you can monetise themodel.Tier 1 CSPGrace Blackwell 200 is super-hot. People want that, but they want it more for training these large-scalemodels.There is also a trend for virtualization Grace Blackwell system to carve that up though for multi-tenancy... youcould leverage these Grace Blackwell power in a smaller footprint to get more tenants.Tier 1 CSPWe believe Google is the biggest user of its own chips for internal inferencing consumption, at about 65%-70%, with Amazon following at about 25% internal chips for internal inferencing consumption. We believeMicrosoft, Oracle Cloud, Apple and Meta are heavily dependent on NVidia.

One of the most common questions we fielded this week was "Who will be the winners of Section 232 Tariff announcement.
In the near- term we believe all analog/MCU stocks benefit, as our checks have suggested tariffs were delaying restocking, thus tariff certainty should lead to resumption in restocking
Longer- term, we believe US tariffs will benefit geographically diverse IDMs such as TXN, GFS, ON (and perhaps INTC?)
In the chart on the right, we offer our estimates across coverage regarding internal vs external manufacturing mix and geographical diversity within internal capabilities
We believe geographically diverse IDMs will benefit most in this tariff environment
And potentially INTC - though there is still plenty of wood to chop regarding their Foundry turnaround story
Our Checks: Tariff uncertainty delayed restocking cycle Therefore: Tariff certainty should resume restocking cycle
TXN, GFS, ON INTC...?
Source: Company Data, Evercore ISI Research

Source: Company Data, Evercore ISI Research

Looking at aggregate EMS inventory dollars, we show that over the past 25 years, restocking cycles have typically lasted 5- to- 8 quarters
As of 2Q25 we are 2- quarters off absolute inventory troughs and only 1- quarter off when adjusting for ASP inflation
So we believe we are very much in the early innings of the restocking cycle

Figure 35: Three Key Impacts from Tariffs
Impact #1: Tariff Uncertainty Delays Restocking Risk: Restock today, get stuck with high- cost inventory Tariffs \(=\) OEMs hit credit limits faster (e.g., \(\) 8K\(order +\) \ \(7K\) tariff)
Impact #2: Pushing OEMs to Locally Sourced Chips
OEMs designs prioritize locally sourced chips over functionality Positive for TXN due to vertically integrated manufacturing
Impact #3: Adds Massive Complexity for Supply Chain
Different costs for same SKU based on tariff changes - where die manufactured - where chip packaged, assembled, tested, etc Same SKU now has different part numbers for those permutations
Source: Company Data, Evercore ISI Research
FULL NOTE HERE: Tariffs Delay Restocking Cycle
We are in the middle of a dozen channel checks focused on the analog/MCU industry. Checks were with Automotive OEMs, Resellers, EMS, Tier- 1s, and Chip Manufacturers. Key takes include:

China strong, Europe & US stable to improving Some tariff- related pre- buying, but also general re- stocking BYD cutting production seen as move away from price war, could be period of time with slower production levels at BYD offset by higher content per vehicle Emerging market demand from LatAm and India to be meaningful in 2026

Al remains hot, momentum to continue into 2026 Industrial improving broadly, though Medical may soften into 3Q Traditional Computing steady Consumer demand "mid- cycle" veering on "late- cycle" US Reseller: Book- to- Bill 1.05

Some Tariff- Related Pre- Buying, Mainly Auto, But Generally Mild ImpactIDM: Saw spike in orders/deliveries initially, slight channel overstock, but largely recoveredEMS: Generally speaking no tariff pull- ins in Medical, few customers but not consensus, more wait and seeEMS: Customers having conversations about using more regional distributors if tariffs remain issue, but no changes yetUS Reseller: Tariffs not really creating pre- buys, end customer will ultimately carry brunt of tariff costsEuropean Auto OEM: Some pull- forward from tariffs in Mar/Apr, eased in May/Jun, mild overall impact, mostly for higher ASP "critical" chipsAsia Auto Tier 1: Pre- buying throughout 2Q and parts of 3Q, likely to come to end "soon", 4Q could be period of depletionSeveral: Tariffs not enough to create reshoring due to lower non- US labor costs, other factors

European Auto OEM: Generally stable, extending in specialized IC's and power semis...BYD creating allocation challenges in EVEMS: Lead times stableUS Reseller: Lead times stable, some pockets of extensionEuropean Auto OEM: Lead times stable

2Q Inventories Stable to Higher SequentiallyAsia Tier- 1: Inventory weeks up to 6- to- 8 weeks, in some cases 12- weeks vs prior 4- to- 6 weeksEuropean Auto OEM: Inventories "back to normal" at 7- to- 8 weeksEMS: Slight increase in near- term inventories, expected to deplete in 3QEuropean Reseller: Inventories flat at 5- to- 6 weeksEuropean Auto OEM: Slight increase in inventory, mild overall

- European Auto OEM: Pricing stable, advanced SoC ASPs could increase in 2026- Chipmaker: Pricing stable- EMS: 2025 pricing stable, expect LSD-MSD% declines moving forward, but no "mean-reversion" to pre-COVID- US Reseller: analog/MCU companies no longer offering price discounts for higher volume orders- European Auto OEM: Expects 4-6% price declines in 2025 (vs prior expects HSD-LDD%), but high-end parts could see price increases- Asia Auto Tier-1: Pricing stable

- In Auto, China competition increasing in areas such as Silicon Carbide, low-end MCUs, adv SoCs, infotainment – but not competitive in analog, higher-density power (in DCs), higher-end MCUs- Rare Earths huge focus past 3mos, China using as negotiation tool, been close to shortages in Auto- China (Semis) for China (OEMs) trend expected to continue, one suggests China can grow from 30-40% of cars to 50-60% by 2030- Silicon Carbide competition in 4-to-5yrs at device level, unlikely to catch up to IFX/ON quality, but "good enough" particularly given lower ASPs- BYD God's Eye L2+/L2++ ADAS roll-out "impressive", other Chinese EVs expected to follow- BYD struggling to gain share in Europe mainly due to lack of physical dealer presence creating challenges around servicing cars- BYD cutting production seen as function of state subsidies leading to overcapacity in China in general – estimates 38-to-40m cars vs domestic market 25m – exports not growing enough to bridge gap

- European Auto OEM: NVDA leading for high-level autonomy ADAS functionality, but IFX and NXPI doing well in general in ADAS as well- Chipmaker: TXN touting US manufacturing presence as geopolitical lever, advantage in US vs IFX and even ADI...TXN "force to be reckoned with"- Chipmaker: ADI struggling with AI power so far, IFX, TXN and MPWR doing best- EMS: Brokers holding standard parts on behalf of OEMs, and EMS companies developing own standard parts, expected to be risk for catalog parts (TXN, MCHP possibly impacted)- European Auto OEM; STM, NXPI and TXN managed cycle well- US Reseller: analog/MCU utilization rates increased from 60% at beginning of 2025 to 70% on average- US Reseller: MCHP and ON still dealing with cycle mis-management hangover- European Auto OEM: IFX best positioned, NXPI and STM more mixed- European Reseller: IFX biggest gainer

The MCU market has historically grown at a \(2.4\%\) CAGR, but more recently has accelerated to \(5.4\%\) driven by higher performance 32- bit MCUs, and increased penetration of silicon in the Automotive market

We think growth could continue to accelerate as edge/IoT devices in Auto, Industrial and Consumer markets continue to grow in popularity and require higher processing power for local functionality and AI
Figure 36: MCU Revenue CAGR Has Accelerated to \(5.4\%\) from \(2.8\%\) , Driven by the 32-bit Segment
Source: Company Data, Evercore ISI Research, Gartner
The Automotive MCU market has grown at an \(11\%\) CAGR over the past 5 years, the fastest growing end market

We believe that the \(- 1\% - 5\%\) year CAGR for Industrial understates true growth, as we think the Industrial market saw the biggest inventory build, and more recently the biggest inventory correction due to the multi- tiered / multi- layered nature of the supply chain that sells into Industrial end markets
Figure 37: MCU Market Growth By End-Market, Led by Automotive Past 5 Years
Source: Company Data, Evercore ISI Research, Gartner
The MCU industry has consolidated to 6 companies accounting for \(85\%\) of the market today, from 10 companies 10 years ago
IFX has been the largest share gainer over the past two years, driven by its strong position with key China EV makers
China vendors represent approximately \(9\%\) share of the overall MCU industry, where share has been largely stagnant for the past 3 years
Figure 13: Six Companies Account for \(85\%\) of the MCU Market, down from Ten 10 yrs Ago
Source: Company Data, Evercore ISI Research, Gartner
As the industry consolidated, operating margins expanded by 130bps/yr for the past 12 years, or by 1,600bps in aggregate

After normalizing post the current inventory correction, we expect them to continue to expand at a rate of 100bps/yr, as long product life cycles in MCUs benefit from refresh well after consolidation happens
Figure 14: MCU Gross & Operating Margins Expanded 80bps & 130bps per Year Trough-to-Trough
Source: Company Data, Evercore ISI Research, FactSet
MCHP has the highest exposure to MCUs, at 53% of total revenues, and is the market leader in the 8-bit MCU market
MCHP, Renesas and NXPI have the highest exposure to the high- growth 32- bit MCU market
TXN has the lowest MCU exposure at 8%
Figure 40: MCHP Has Highest Exposure to MCUs
Source: Company Data, Evercore ISI Research, Gartner

Consumer and Compute markets account for \(70\%\) of China MCU revenues, which we believe have a large local component to them and are slower growing and lower margin businesses. Auto, the fastest growing market accounting for \(47\%\) of global MCU spend, accounts for only \(9\%\) of China MCU revenues where it has only \(2\%\) share
5 local China companies represented \(50\%\) of the \(\sim \$ 2B\) China MCU revenues in 2024 - CEC Huada, GigaDevice, Unigroup Guoxin, Fudan Micro and Sino Wealth Electronics
...those 5 companies have grown in aggregate at \(+7\%\) 5- year CAGR since 2019...
...CEC Huada has the largest share ( \(12\%\) of China MCU) ...
...fastest growth on 3yr CAGR - Nationz, Eastsoft, CR Micro, XTX technology and Ninestar
...on 2yr basis - Bluestrum, Eastsoft, Puy, CR Micro and SemiDrive
Check appendix for writeups on each of these China MCU companies
Figure 45: Five Chinese Companies Accounted for \(50\%\) of China MCU Revenues in 2024
Source: Company Data, Evercore ISI Research, Gartner

Our logic has been that we should see a troughing and positive inflection in business trends in the same order that they saw the correction, i.e., we suggested TXN as top analog name first as it was first to see the correction, and later MCHP as it saw the correction 4- qtrs after TXN...
...we are shifting ON and NXPI to top ideas as they were the latest to see the inventory correction and we believe will be the next to see a troughing and positive inflection in fundamentals
Figure 46: Analog/MCU Cycle Playbook Suggests Shifting to ON & NXPI
Source: Company Data, Evercore ISI Research

H20s OK Again? In a blog on its website, NVDA said it was filing applications to sell its H20 GPUs again, and that the US government has assured NVDA that licenses will be granted, and NVDA hopes to start deliveries soon. The blog was released following NVDA CEOs recent trips to Washington DC and Beijing. The blog also reaffirmed the company's support for the US Administration's effort to create jobs, strengthen domestic AI infrastructure and onshore manufacturing and ensure that America leads in AI worldwide.

Potentially \(\) 10bn\$ in Near- Term Revenues Once Approved. Recall that when the H20 restrictions were originally announced, NVDA took \(\) 5.5bn\$ in write- downs, \(50\%\) for purchase commitments, and \(50\%\) for product. Assuming \(70 - 75\%\) GM on \(\) 2.75bn\$ of inventories would imply about \(\) 10bn\$ in revenues anticipate from those written down inventories on hand, but since the product was written down, that would suggest much higher gross margins on that \(\) 10bn\$ of revenues

China Becoming Less Important As AI Ramps Globally. We estimate that over the past 5 years, China has declined from \(20 - 25\%\) of NVDA revenues to \(10 - 15\%\) more recently. More recently, our analysis indicates that Tier 2 Cloud Service Providers are ramping AI infrastructure buildouts globally, with NVDA as the solution of choice. We estimate Cloud CapEx grows by over \(50\%\) in 2025, following \(56\%\) growth in 2026. Separately, our checks have indicated high demand for NVDA's latest solution Blackwell, and high visibility for demand for Blackwells through 2025 and into 2026.

2030 EPS Power of \(\) 13.30\(. Our analysis of previous Tectonic Shifts in computing shows that typically one vertically integrated ecosystem captures\) 80\%\$ of the value created during each computing era, and that each computing era typically last 15- 20 years and is 10x the size of the previous era. We've argued that NVDA would be that player in the current computing era, and continue to estimate a bull- case 2030 EPS power of\) \ \(13.30\) . See notes here and here

China GPU License Under Review. According to AMD, the US Department of Commerce recently informed it that its license to ship MI308X to China will be moving forward for review. AMD plans to resume shipments once the license is approved and expects to offer a detailed update on the progress at its earnings call on August \(5^{\text{th}}\)

Potential Near Term Revenue Upside of \(\) 700m\(, Medium Term Upside Potential of\) \ \(1.5bn\) . AMD previously estimated - \(\) 700m\(revenue reduction in 2Q related to restrictions and a full - year negative impacts to C2025 revenues\) \ \(1.5bn\) . We currently estimate AMD's C2025 GPU revs at \(\) 6bn\(and view\) \ \(700m\) as a near term potential revenue upside.

Potential for 2Q GM Upside vs Guide. AMD expected a \(1x\) \(\) 800m\(write - down related to the inventory and purchase commitments in AprQ resulting in 1100bps GM headwind guiding 2Q GM at\) 43\% \(vs\) 54\% \(unaffected). It is not clear if AMD booked entire write - downs in April, but we believe that MI308X products are higher GMs vs other Instinct GPUs, and should the shipments resume we anticipate tailwind to GMs.

Our checks indicate that a new vector of demand for AI infrastructure is emerging from a new set of Tier 2 cloud service providers, which is reflected in NVDA and AMD announcements. We estimate 2025 CapEx for Tier 1 players at \(60\%\) growth to \$355bn+, but when adding Tier 2+ players, we estimate that increases to \(72\%\) growth to nearly \$440bn. We do not believe we are incorporating all the Tier 2+ cloud players in our sample set, and suspect if we did, that the aggregate 2025 CapEx would indicate and acceleration of demand over 2024 levels.
Our key takes from NVDA at GTC in Paris:
NVDA estimates over the course of the next several years \(\sim \$ 1.5\) Tn worth of Al capacity to be built out globally.
European Al Infrastructure to increase 10x from 2024 to 2026 as measured by number of GPU dies.

NVDA highlighted Al infrastructure projects from 5 European Telcos, 19 CSPs and 16 Supercomputing centers all for local compute consumption and using NVDA hardware. NVDA expects EU government to support buildout of 20 Al factories with a handful of them being gigafactories. Overall NVDA expects 20 gigafactories (\$40- 50bn per gigawatt) over the coming years - all incremental to US CSPs
We note that this is consistent with our own Al channel checks suggesting significant infrastructure European buildout by local and Tier 2 players in addition to US top 4 hyperscalers.
NVDA opens 7 Al technology centers across Europe to grow regional research and startup ecosystem.
NVDA expects digital twins and robotics industries to be in large demand with European manufacturers listing 6 manufacturing or logistics digital twins projects underway in Europe.

Compared to Europe, Middle East announcements included "some indigenous use, but it's really about hosting the cloud for American companies", whereas European capacity is offered by local vendors for local consumption.

Observing top hyperscalers capex estimates now vs 12 months ago (Charts #1 and #2) we note (1) CapEx forecasts continue to only get revised upwards over time and (2) addition of Tier 2 CSP players to the sample makes the growth rates see no deceleration on YY growth in C2025. And this sample does not include any of the European gigawatt factories and other Al investments being made.

"We could place a few- hundred- billion dollar order on our supply chain because we have great confidence of the end market and the fungibility of our products everywhere"
GB300 transition on schedule

We view AMD's Advancing AI event consistent with our latest AI Channel Checks, which indicated that AMD is making progress on ROCm software stack as well as in penetrating hyperscalers internal inferencing workloads, as hyperscalers strive to diversify their AI chip supplier base. We maintain estimates but increase our price target to \(\) 144\(based on\) 21x C27 EPS of \(\) 7.54\(discounted back at\) 10\%\$ , as we view increased visibility on datacenter GPUs as warranting a higher P/E multiple. Our key takes from advancing AI event:

- MI350 series in production and will be available in 3Q25 and expected to offer inference \(4x\) gen-on-gen AI compute increase in FP4 and FP6 and up to \(40\%\) more tokens per dollar and \(2.6x+\) improvement for pre-training and fine-tuning.

- AMD Instinct customer list expanded from META, ORCL and MSFT to add OpenAI, xAI, Cohere, RedHat and Humain. Our own AI channel checks suggest an increasing traction with customers as at least 3 out of the top 7 US hyperscalers (MSFT, META and ORCL) are using AMD in production for inferencing uses cases. We note customers highlighted demand for flexible and programmable compute hardware given unprecedented speed of the industry evolution and changes in software approach.

- META expanded use cases beyond original Llama inferencing to include AI recommendation inference & training- xAI described using AMD GPUs in production as "effortless"- Oracle mentioned AMD's addition of PyTorch and LLM support as an accelerator to customer momentum
- AMD released ROCm 7 optimized for reasoning and agentic AI. AMD's benchmarks suggest ROCm 7 offers \(3x+\) performance improvement vs ROCm 6:
- An average of \(3.5x\) performance improvement for inference for Llama 3.1 70B, Qwen2-72B and DeepSeek R1- An average \(3x\) performance improvement for Llama 2 70B, Lama 3.1 8B and Qwen 1.5 7B
- AMD increased focus on developer community. Our own checks AMD is making some progress on this front. We view the latest announcements as incremental:

- AMD expands ROCm on client Ryzen and Radeon devices and offers in-box Linus and full Windows support- AMD offers Developer Cloud for an easy access to AMD compute for developers and open-source contributors
Full Note: AMD: Advancing AI: ROCm and Developer Community Focus

We estimate sales of AMD's datacenter GPU product, Instinct, will increase by \(\) 600m/+\$ 70% QQ to \(\) 1.6bn in 3Q25 - AMD management indicated that step- function growth will be driven by the ramp of its \(3^{\mathrm{rd}}\) gen MI350/MI355 products. Management also indicated that the ramp of the MI350 products would broaden AMD's customer base and workloads. Older generation, MI300/325, will continue shipping into inferencing workloads.

AMD noted Microsoft, Meta and Oracle as customers (consistent with our checks). AMD also noted a new multi- billion engagement with Oracle and first 30K MI355 chips expected to be deployed in 2H25. Separately, AMD said it was adding a frontier AI model maker as a customer to use AMD.

Compared to MI300/MI325, MI355 offers (1) \(+55\%\) performance improvement, (2) scaling capabilities allowing AMD to create mid- size training clusters, (3) software features for ROCm and support for FP4 and FP6 inference data types The MI300 family is largely used for inferencing workloads, and AMD management expects MI350 and MI400 to increase AMD's exposure to training workloads: MI350 for mid- size LLMs, MI400 for larger LLMs. MI400 is designed for much greater scale- up capabilities vs MI350 (in addition to scale out)

AMD's aspiration is to make ROCm the industry's Open- Source stack of choice. It has ramped investment into ROCm adding \(\sim 800\) software engineers last year through M&A and hiring for a total of several thousand employees. AMD has increased the software release cadence of ROCm to 2x/month recently vs 1x/quarter previously AMD made the case that ROCm's improvement can be seen in its success in getting AI models to be performant out of the box / on Day 1. AMD has focused its development resources on increasing the number of working models by working with hyperscalers.

AMD management believes that AI workloads continue to evolve at extraordinary speed and that programmable merchant GPUs will account for the majority of AI compute share, due to their flexibility. AMD expects ASICs to co- exist with GPUs, largely targeting more stable algorithms. Consistent with our checks, AMD believes customers want a sustainable GPU competitor with scale.

Instinct gross margins remain below corporate average and are expected to improve towards corporate longer term, but near- term AMD prioritizing gross margin dollars and focuses on ramping revenues with margin improvement to follow over time

AMD does not see any slowdown in its server CPU share gains and expects to gain an additional 200- 500bps of share in 2025, particularly as it improves its presence in \(3^{\text{rd}}\) party cloud, China cloud and telecom enterprises.

TCO is key consideration, and AMD expanded its server CPU SKUs to improve TCO for different cloud data center topologies. AMD noted AMZN's rollout of ARM CPUs but the rest of cloud vendors are much earlier in the deployment cycle and would require significant software buildout for ARM CPUs, so AMD continues to expect share gains in Server CPUs.

AMD CPU availability at all cloud vendors makes it easy for enterprises to shift workloads between cloud vendors and on prem w/out needing to recompile software. AMD believes it is underrepresented in telecom market, but noted that customers who did TCO analysis typically convert.

AMD noted \(68\%\) YY growth in its client CPU business in 1Q25, which was driven by a \(43\%\) YY increase in ASPs largely due to a strong uptake in its higher- ASP gaming product line. AMD management believes it is gaining share in high- end gaming and content creation markets vs past stronger market share in lower end consumer markets With regard to the risk of growth being driven by tariff- related pull- ins, management suggested that while pull- ins could have happened in 1Q25, but that it believes that better 1Q25 seasonality was due at least in part due to new program ramps (like Dell)

AMZN's 13F showed a new 822K share position of AMD. AMD management explained that AMZN's new AMD position was a result of AMD's acquisition of ZT Systems (closed 31- Mar- 25), a company in which AMZN held warrants in ZT that converted to AMD stock when the deal closed.

Management believes that its GPU business market share ramp is viewed as slow by investors, but noted it is pursuing similar LT strategy (with same executive team) that proved successful in winning share server CPUs, and that it is seeing success along a similar time frame. That being that the \(1^{\text{st}}\) gen product is introductory (MI300 in GPUs, Naples in server CPUs), \(2^{\text{nd}}\) gen (MI325, Rome) onboards a large customer, \(3^{\text{rd}}\) gen (MI350, Milan) larger customers onboarding and continued market share gains follow in \(4^{\text{th}}\) gen (Genoa, MI400) and beyond.

AMD believes that while investors are hyper- focused on its progress in its datacenter GPU business, they perhaps do not fully appreciate that the company continues to see strong momentum in all markets (GPU, CPU and Client), and that its profitability benefits from having a strong position in all 3 markets.

We view the PC Era and Cellphone/x86 server computing eras as having ubiquitous computing architectures - 300m identical PCs and a billion identical handsets made annually meant it paid to optimize isolated functions on different chips, and throw them over the wall for the OEM to integrate onto a PCB

In a data intensive, highpower consumption computing world, each functional element needs to be designed with other elements in mind, and integrated by the semi company into a single chip. As important, not only are the chips different, but the board the processor sits on is different, as is the system the board plugs into. The successful processor chip company must not only have SoC capabilities, but the ability to design the total compute system.
We estimate that the total data processor will grow to \(\) 160bn-\ \(200bn by 2030, with custom - Al chip market to be one - third of that, or\) \sim \$ 80bn

INTC hosted its Foundry Direct Connect Event to update its foundry strategy. We summarize our notes from presentations by CEO Lip- Bu Tan, Naga Chandrasekaran (EVP, CTO and COO Intel Foundry) and Kevin O'Buckley (SVP, GM Foundry Services):

1) A Customer-Centric Focus. All 3 INTC speakers highlighted INTC's shift to a customer-focused approach for the foundry business prioritizing customer feedback and a focus on improving predictability, quality, velocity and affordability of INTC's foundry offering. COO suggested new approach to measuring Foundry success would be driven by value customers get from INTC Foundry rather than what INTC delivers to the customers. We view this as a notably different approach and are encouraged by the renewed focus. Intel shared customer feedback on it 18A process and roadmap:

a. INTC noted customer feedback that 18A is not targeted towards broader market and was designed for high performance compute applications and INTC plans to offer 18A-P version to customers for broader ecosystem featuring \(\sim 8\%\) performance improvement vs 18A, additional ribbon size, corner tightening. 
b. INTC highlighted customers' need for predictable 2-yr design cycles for nodes. INTC noted 14A being its second node with backside power technology as it expects 18A ramp learnings to make 14A transition execution more predictable.

2) Three Foundry Nodes. INTC is ramping 3 foundry nodes: 16nm (Ireland fab) together with MediaTek as a "teaching customer", 12nm (in Arizona fab) in a joint venture with "teaching partner" UMC and 18A in Oregon (with Arizona fab to ramp shortly).
a. MediaTek products taped out from the fab and according to MediaTek INTC's responsiveness to challenges was "remarkable"

3) \(\) 90bn\(in CapEx + Ability to Expand. INTC spent\) \ \(90bn\) on Capex in C21-24 and it estimates \(20\%\) of that related to R&D / competitiveness and \(80\%\) on expanding footprint and technology transition (space - 39\%\) and equipment - 41%). INTC highlighted that it can easily add customer capacity within 6-8 quarters across its fabs in Arizona, Oregon, Israel and in the future, Ohio.

4) Advanced Packaging capacity is being added in Malaysia and New Mexico in addition to Oregon, highlighting customer demand for large-scale EMIB (>12 reticle sizes), Foveros and Foveros Direct packaging technologies. INTC particularly highlighted its weakness in advanced packaging ecosystem, which it is now focused on fixing.

a. INTC announced an EMIB assembly partnership with Amkor to support INTC's customers supply diversification efforts. Amkor expects to enable INTC's EMIB process in its Korea fab by end of C2026 and grow beyond that.

5) CPO Gen2 in '25 + 3D Photonics in '27. INTC is also offering co-packaged optics capabilities for AI scale-up and scale-out with 1st gen CPO launched in 2024 using direct fiber attach technology and expected transition to gen 2 technology in 2025 using optical package connector and ultimately 3D photonics in C2027 with vertical expanded beam coupling

Two of the secular trends in SCE- "bigger chips" and "more complex transistors and packaging"- can be attributed to limits in semiconductor physics

After 35 years of consistently doubling of transistors and clock speeds of chips every 2- to- 3 years, transistors became so small that they could no longer be run faster without overheating. This led to three foundational changes in the industry:
1) CPU companies had to add more processor cores to chips (blue scatter) making them bigger...
2) ...which in turn led to the need for advanced packaging (e.g., 2.5D and 3D chips)
3) Transistor architecture was changed from simple 2D, to complex 3D FinFET and GAA architectures
This chart illustrates how hitting this physical limit translated to larger die size chips

Historically, processors sold into data centers by companies like AMD, INTC and NVDA were stable in size at 300- to- 500 sq mm over time. As they added more processor cores to compensate for no clock- speed improvement, the chips grew in size, past the limit of the equipment to make them in a single chip
Today's datacenter processors are now in the 1,500 sq mm range, and require advanced packaging techniques to stitch "chiplets" together in a single package - both increase SCE requirements per chip

Every 15- 20 years over the past 60, an accumulation of innovations has led to tectonic shifts in the computing industry. We believe that we are 5- 8 years into the shift to an IoT / Parallel Processing Era, from a Cell Phone Server Era.

Every era is \(\sim 10x\) the size of the previous in units, and historically, one vertically integrated ecosystem company (chip + hardware + software) dominates each era, capturing \(50\% - 80\%\) of the value created during the era and offering the biggest returns for investors. In the Mainframe Era this was IBM, in minicomputers it was DEC. The PC Era was the only horizontal era, with INTC providing the processor, MSFT the software and DELL the hardware. In the Cell Phone / Server Era, Nokia was the ecosystem play in feature phones, and Apple the ecosystem play in smart phones.

We believe alpha is most easily generated to the right of each Tectonic Shift. We favor NVDA, AMD, AVGO and MRVL as top parallel processing plays, and view NVDA as the vertically integrated ecosystem player poised to capture the most value on the parallel processing side of this computing era. On the IoT side we view TXN, ADI, MCHP and NXPI as top plays, although evolving to chips+system solution providers as opposed to a full blown chip + hardware + full- stack software solutions provider.

In this weekly's charts on China, we focus on 11 key product categories - 1) Analog, 2) MCUs, 3) Discretes, 4) Optoelectronics, 5) Nonoptical Sensors, 6) Wired Connectivity chips, 7) Wireless connectivity chips, 8) RF Front- end and Transceivers, 9) Power Management ICs, 10) Display Driver ICs and 11) Touch and Display Drivers.
More info on what is included in each product category below:

1. Analog: Includes monolithic analog and mixed-signal ICs including data converters, switch ICs, multiplexer ICs, voltage regulators, voltage references, timing controller ICs, amplifier ICs, interface ICs, and gate driver ICs  
2. Microcontrollers: Includes 8-bit, 16-bit and 32-bit MCUs  
3. Discretes: Includes small-signal diodes, power diodes, Schottky barrier diodes, RF diodes, Zener diodes, transient voltage suppressors, other protection diodes, small-signal transistors, power transistors, RF transistors, and thyristors  
4. Optoelectronics: Includes CCD image sensors, CMOS image sensors, mini-LED, single LED, photodiodes, phototransistors, photoresistors, and couplers  
5. Nonoptical Sensors: Includes environmental sensors (pressure, temperature, humidity), fingerprint sensors, inertial sensors (acceleration, yaw rate, level, spin), magnetic sensors, MEMS microphones, and other sensors (ISFET pH meters, MEMS-based ultrasonic sensors, gas and chemical sensors, etc.)  
6. Wired Connectivity: Includes wide range of wired interface controller chips including buffers, framers, front-ends, isolators, link layer controllers, MACs, PHY controllers, power line networking devices, protectors, receivers, repeaters, sample rate converters, SerDes, subscriber line interface circuits, storage interfaces, transmitters, transceivers, terminators or universal asynchronous receiver/transmitter UARTs  
7. Wireless Connectivity: Includes connectivity chips that decode and/or encode radio signal conforming to specific transmission standards including Wi-Fi, Bluetooth, NFC, IEEE 802.15.4, GPS but does not include cellular-based technologies  
8. RF Front-End and Transceivers (RFFE): Includes transceivers, transmitters, receivers and application specific RF devices, primarily transceivers, power amplifiers, LNAs, antenna switches and antenna tuners  
9. Power Management: Includes power management ICs that combine multiple power management functions within a single chip focused on voltage scaling, power source selection, battery charging/monitoring, and power sequencing. Features include linear regulators, DC-DC converters, LED or display drivers, and battery management  
10. Display Drivers (DDIC): Includes LCD DDICs and OLED DDICs  
11. Touch and Display Driver Integration (TDDI): TDDI are special types of display drivers where display driver and touch functions are integrated into a single chip and exclude discrete touch ICs

Evercore ISI's recommendations are based on a stock's total forecasted return over the next 12 months. Total forecasted return is equal to the expected percentage price return plus gross dividend yield. We divide our stocks under coverage into three primary ratings categories, with the following return guidelines:
Outperform- the total forecasted return is expected to be greater than the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector.
In Line- the total forecasted return is expected to be in line with the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector.
Underperform- the total forecasted return is expected to be less than the expected total return of the analyst's coverage sector.
